author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok gang, here’s something I’ve been pondering

Imagine 3 sliders that go from 0 to 10. Your goal is to set the sliders to maximize your wellbeing (in the broadest sense) and the wellbeing of those close to  you. The sliders are in effect zero sum, in that the closer you are to one end then less you have of the attribute on the other end. Let’s set the time horizon to 25 years and acknowledge the seemingly increasing pace of change in the world

Ok, the sliders …

**#1 Classics vs Cutting Edge**
On this slider 0 represents maximum knowledge in a classical sense - literature, math, mythology, fundamental accepted basics in Biology/Chemistry/Physics etc etc. 10 represents complete literacy in the cutting edge of culture, science and technology - from memes and Reddit culture to AI to synthetic biology and Blockchain etc etc 

**#2 Specialist vs Generalist**
Here 0 represents a very deep and specific knowledge of a chosen field (could be a doctor or a producer) vs 10 representing a modern Jack of all trades who knows a little bit about a lot of things 

**#3 Short Term vs Long Term**
On the slider 0 represents a disposition all about short term wins, fast plays that close out over a year vs 10 representing long investments in a given idea/field/belief system

It goes without saying that the zero sum aspect here is artificial, you can of course have some long term plays happening alongside some short term, but it’s just to get the juices flowing

author: Slow Hand
content:
Fun question! I hate to complicate an already nuanced premise at the outset, but when I observe my own choices and think of each category I see myself living both sides of all three spectrums, but in different domains:

**For example:** I could be short-term in career objectives and overt achievement and long-term oriented in relationships and satisfaction. Cutting edge in creative pursuits, but classics in my personal taste. Specialist in my mode of expression, and generalist in my interests.

The more I subdivide and examine the question the more I find exceptions to everything. I am steeped in knowledge, but I seek wisdom above most things, which some philosophies would consider contradictory.

This Anais Nin quote comes to mind:

> "We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another, unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made of layers, cells, constellations."

I think people are extremely lopsided and unbalanced when you start to drill down into their psyches, and that's wonderful! 

For the sake of refining this question and narrowing the scope, should we confine these three axis to only record making? Or do we want to approach it in a holistic sense?

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve always gone with the (very true) “I don’t think I’m the guy that can push this particular track forward. I want to make sure you’re stoked on the end result and I don’t think my particular skill set is going to get you there. I’d love to recommend you to A,B,C who could probably do a better job with this”. Two things happen: 1) the artist respects you for genuinely caring about their outcome and not just doing a money grab, and 2) you’re in the position of helping your contemporaries get work. The thing I’m most proud of in my discography is that most people I work with I work with more than once, and that’s a direct result of the amount of work I turn down.

Just don’t send anything to @cian riordan

author: LAPhill
content:
There was a line in The Assistant's Handbook that we were required to read at Berklee. Something to the effect of "the only people that will understand you are other engineers, and who would want to marry one of them?" 

In all seriousness, there are plenty of people that are doing this full-time that have partners and families. Speaking only for myself, my wife has zero musical background. It's frankly really nice at the end of a long day to listen to what she's been up to, or talk about any of the things we connect on besides music and turn work-mode off. The right person will understand your passion and support you, they don't have to live it themselves. But you also need to show up and support them in their own endeavors and interests. It'll make you a more well-rounded human.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

The refresh rate on most TVs is slower than on a monitor, so you'll feel more latency. Even ones that do the hyper-real sports setting (motion smoothing) to display 120-240Hz will actually introduce MORE latency for that processing. 

If you can find a TV with a game mode, that's typically low-latency and you'd likely be fine.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I've worked in digital automotive as a product designer for almost 10 years, both on the new and used side. 

1. Unlikely. Supply chain is still in shock from 2020. Probably won't fully be recovered for another 18-24 months.
2. Depends on the need. For a business, leasing probably makes more sense than owning. The lease can be taken as a deduction.
3. If you are buying new, you will eat the depreciation cost. If you are buying used, the depreciation is already priced in. If you want a relatively new car, I will always recommend going Certified Pre-Owned. One of the better deals in automotive with the benefit of a likely extended warranty coverage. There are plenty of high quality used vehicles out there that are effectively new (full disclosure, I work for Carvana...the vehicles are reconditioned similar to CPO standard). My last I don't know how many cars have all been gently used late-model used cars. Cars these days are more durable and reliable than they've ever been. Low risk in buying late-model used. I will only ever buy used anymore.
4. Whoever offers you the lowest APR. That is often the captive lender, but rates are a bit of a cluster fuck these days so shop around for the lowest. One fun fact: if you are buying from a dealer, APR's are negotiable. They will tell you that's the best they can do, but they take margin on the loan. There's meat on the bone there if you want to do battle. 
5. Car prices can fluctuate seasonally yes, but wouldn't try and time the market. You won't save that much.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I have a scalding hot take that the “indie girl” voice isn’t a fad and came about because it’s the optimal way to sing for the medium. 

Think of how opera doesn’t sound like human speech. That alien sound came about because extremely loose muscles create far less sympathetic intermodulation which sounds cleaner. It’s the same as how a speaker makes your desk vibrate and create out of time interference pattern distortions. Muscle tension creates hard surfaces that do the same when singing and opera singers obsess over undoing this. This is a big reason why so many of your favorite vocalists are opioid and benzo addicts. It’s not just culture. Downers are performance enhancing here. (Please don’t get any ideas artists) 

The modern pop voice is just maintaining that exaggerated opera looseness but with adaptations for the modern medium: English diphthongs instead of Latin ones, way less air in their lungs because the target is a foot from their mouth instead of 50 feet, and softened fricatives because a capsule right in front of the mouth harshly exaggerates fricatives. 

From a physics perspective it’s the perfectly optimized way to sing in 2024. You may not like it, but this is what peak performance sounds like

author: Slow Hand
content:
Now I'm curious. How do y'all normally use Spotify? I've got a few modes:

1. I know exactly what I want to hear. I search it and start listening.

2. If I'm less picky I choose an album from an artist and listen through it entirely.

3. I put my *Liked Songs* playlist (roughly 2k songs, anything goes) on shuffle and let it rip.

4. Thurs at 9p I listen to my *Release Radar* playlist for the new releases from artists I follow.

5. Monday morning I listen to my *Discover Weekly* playlist and listen to the 30 songs it's recommending me.

Those are the main ways that I engage with the app. Is anyone here doing something significantly different? Radio stations maybe? Specific playlists?

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good way to summarize the benefit of Andrej's approach here is by looking at two different ways to go about learning how a frog works: 

1) You can dissect a frog to learn about it. You observe the long legs, the muscles, the skin, the eyes, the respiratory system, etc. You see it's strengths and you see it's weaknesses and you draw your conclusions from there. This would be the top-down learning approach. It's good at describing what already *is*. 

Or...

2) You build/design a frog from scratch. You will quickly come to understand why things *have* to be the way they are. You realize that all of the evolutionary "choices" about a frog's physiology are simply the best possible compromises, given the pressures of the environment, the availability of resources, and the limits of physics. By building it yourself you will come to perceive all of the invisible challenges and "solved" problems that were required to make an organism that will simply survive, much less thrive.

This firsthand experience of building the thing will actually make you an expert because you've done the hard work and experienced it for yourself. You took ten paths to failure and made every mistake before settling on a a non-obvious compromise that allows you to balance it against every other factor. You understand *why* it needs to be that way.

This knowledge will make you robust and flexible, whereas top-down knowledge is more superficial and brittle. If the conditions of your subject change and the model you understand is no longer relevant then you're in a far more precarious place than someone who's built something from the ground up.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I often use the proMB freeband mode as a basic “denoiser” for high end. 

If I get a vocal with some schmutzy noise, I will dip the high end, but have the lower vocal fundamentals trigger expansion back to a “flat” frequency whenever the vocal is actually singing. Release time to taste from there.

Can also help with an over resonant drum or lower “hum” issue where you want to dip most of the time, but then have it be “flat” whenever the snare hits, or whatever.

Comes in handy for post work too. Cleaned up a lot of VO’s and SFX recordings with those methods.

Every time this conversation comes up it feels to me like it’s operating at the wrong level of abstraction

I don’t care if you used the most purist documentarian techniques or the “worst” excesses of modern tuning/quantizing/AI etc. I ONLY care if you make me feel things. And I believe most listeners are the same as me

If you somehow believe that modern techniques somehow inhibit or even preclude making feels inducing records then I’ll bet we could collectively provide many many examples proving that wrong 

So it feels to me like if one was to accept that there is something “wrong” with modern music (I don’t) then the existence of music that is “right” made with all of these same modern tools and techniques seems to suggest that the “blame” lays elsewhere

author: Slow Hand
content: Haha yeah. Reminds me of a story from the lapsteel player on Dylan's *Blood On the Tracks*. He was all by himself in this huge tracking room overdubbing lapsteel. After a few takes there'd be a pause while he waited for judgement from the control room. Eventually Dylan stepped out into the live room and got right up into the guy's face and said something really condescending to him about when to play. As Dylan turned away the guy describes having "nothing but contempt for Dylan in that moment" and he got super defiant and went into "Fuck you, Dylan" mode on the next take. Once the take was done he was left in silence to wonder. And as he squinted into the control room he could see everyone laughing their asses off. author: frankieharper
content:
Thought for the end of the day… UK time 

Our arrangements and our mixes leap into existence from the womb of the metaphysical into a world rich in strict guidelines and predetermined boundaries. It’s drill, it NEEDS that thump… it’s lofi, it neeeeeds that blur, I want to get onto New Music Friday, it needs to be LoUd. 

Genre and playlists seem to rule with an iron fist… I often think that when an artist asks for a ‘brighter’ mix or an even MORE colossal 808. Not always… but often. 

Surely the overall and final sonic characteristic of our various musical expressions should be treated with as much emotional sensibility as our lyric or our narrative? 

Perhaps a dark lyric cries out for a dark mix… New Music Friday or otherwise?

Or is that built in?
 *wild generalisation hat firmly secured* 
Would it be too much of a reach to say that modern pop music is bright and loud because in recent history, pop music is high energy and bright in tone? Or is jazz historically observed from the back of a smoky leather bound room and so dark and dynamic just sits comfortably (whisky in hand) … I guess my question is… at risk of sounding a little Orwellian, do we control genre or does genre control us? Probably both? Asking for a friend.

Contemporary trends can have a large payoff if you get on board at the right time, but if you're setting out today to start an education in LLMs and AI programming, that ship might have sailed by the time you're ready to contribute.

More and more I'm beginning to appreciate that there is a gap between people living their lives in meatspace and the perpetually online. There's an entire strata of online discourse that's completely invisible to a lot of people, and they're probably better off for it.

It's odd how disconnected we can be from each other when we don't share the same media spaces. 

Despite the shortcomings of the old media models there were unifying benefits when people were all tuned into a small number of media outlets. I don't expect that will ever come back, but I wonder if there's a way to reduce the complexity of the fractured niche narratives that people are tuned into.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is definitely an interesting period in AI developments. Lots of exciting and novel tools exploding right now that are threatening to replace certain modes of illustration, writing, programming, and audio.

It seems likely that certain roles for creators are going to be diminished. Photography was a huge blow to illustrators when it emerged. Portraiture and photo-realism used to be the domain of painters. But when those skills became trivially easy to replicate the next generation of painters had to pivot into something else that played to the unique strengths of painting. I can't say what the actual causation is for sure, but the entire 20th century was dominated by abstract representation in painting, as one example of what that shift might look like.

Perhaps as creators our domains will need to shift into something else. Something more taste-driven and creative.

These AI tools can emulate pre-existing material well, but they still lack creativity, taste, and informed judgement. So I think the roles that are likely to remain (until another massive development) are matters of taste and curation. Somebody still needs to steer these tools to make something useful or novel.

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the kind of chops that your description seems to hint at, i would say it is all about tieing technique to your ears. (Assuming, you can already hum a melody on the spot and are not tone deaf) 

I wouldnt worry too much about theory and super correct technique. 

The best Way to get anywhere on an instrument is by Playing it, and doing in consistently. Set some realistic goals and just get going, vocabulary and technique Will come naturally if you just keep Playing. 

Fuck Playing scales and inversions and all that for now. 
Just go learn a metric ton of songs and melodies and learn to play them together. Do it by Ear. It Will be tough in the beginning, but you Will get very decent quickly if you just do the most important Thing, which is being consistent.

I would reccomend setting a low minimum to do everyday to keep a realistic goal that you can keep, rather than a higher on you miss every now and then. You can always add more practice but it sucks to miss out on it.

Start with song you want to Sound like and then you can slowly branch out when the style become second Nature for you. 

Sadly there are no tricks or hacks or whatever youtube wants you to beleive to get their clicks. Its all about muscle memory and developing your ears together. And not to Sound like 4 bar loop, but consistency, and do it a lot. I cannot stress that enough. ❤️

author: Adam Thein
content:
Lots of good advice here already!

I think it still worthwhile to maybe run a few scales here and there or at the very least also add some learning of a solo or two to build some right hand dexterity.  When I'm improvising/practicing I like to try and play four note voicings in my right hand and without really thinking too much about theory just do a lot of stepwise motion.  I think just being able to feel your way around the keys and get really really comfortable with it in the same way you are probably really comfortable on fretboards is going to help a lot.  Improvising in a lot of different keys will also be a big help in getting your familiarity honed in.

Another thing that really helped whip me into shape quickly is playing with other people, having to listen and react and find a pocket and not step on other instruments - all of that translates really well into part writing for me now.

There's an interesting point to explore here. We do live in 2023, where mixes and frequency ranges are expected to be in a certain ballpark, by and large. Does that mean that a band like RATM simply couldn't exist today, because their sound doesn't translate to modern sonics? There must be a way to capture the grit and rawness of a band like that while simultaneously sounding modern. 

I guess I don't agree with the idea that RATM couldn't be mixed in a modern style and still be fucking killer. Give me the sonics, but don't edit the thing to within an inch of its life and it'll probably be just fine.

author: LAPhill
content: Sure, but whenever someone says they want the Bonham drum sound, for example, they don't mean it. It sounded big for the time, huge in the arrangement, but if you literally dropped that into a modern mix, it would sound wimpy. We accept the sonics as a part of the totality of a record, in the era it was produced in. Give me the Bonham drum sound experience that's in my brain.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As a soft rule, when I experience something that I don't understand I lean into it, sometimes after a period of being repulsed by it. I'll often find myself continually thinking about a thing that I don't understand, which is usually my cue to lean in and give it a closer look.

Until then I'm constantly theorizing about what it might be and continually updating my mental model as I learn more. Keeping my judgement open the best I can.

It's my opportunity to open up to the world and learn more. It's an ongoing practice and is it's own reward.

It has it's downsides too. Sometimes I take a long time to render judgement and may need to make decisions quicker. I also try not to make many assumptions, which means it sometimes takes me longer to confirm things that other people would take as granted/obvious and just move on.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
haha yeah. i think the compressor thing is more than Jon hates the limitations of compressORS because they are an archaic and limited way to compress the dynamic range compared to all these new tools like saturators and transient shapes and clip gain etc.

as far as clippers at the end, that's the dance right? it's not "keep all transients at all costs forever," it's "make modern competitive records with maximum transients." we use saturators and clippers and other forms of harmonic distortion for their compressing and thickening effect, but the necessarily kill transients. so it's a balance between saturation and transients always. saturators plus transient shapers

author: Slow Hand
content:
Mmhm. At first glance the obvious move seems to be that Spotify could double its subscription rate to $20/month and kick a larger margin towards the artist. I think unlimited music is certainly worth that. Setting aside, for the moment, all of the other complexities around market pricing, we also need to remember that Spotify's largest streaming competitors are Apple and Amazon.

These are companies with massive war-chests derived from the success of their non-streaming companies. Even if Spotify *wanted* to raise the cost of their service, companies like Apple and Amazon can afford to keep the price of streaming services depressed and sustain a loss on their streaming services for far longer than Spotify ever could. To my eyes, Spotify doesn't have a whole lot of wiggle-room to adjust their pricing and therefore their payout models.

I say as much, because in casual discussions around streaming payouts, there doesn't seem to be much awareness of the larger business ecosystem that a company like Spotify finds itself in.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Any band that wouldnt want Andy Wallace is a band I probably wouldn’t want to work with. They clearly confuse frequency response with quality, like someone that thinks a harsh bright mic sounds “better”.

Andy Wallace is brilliant and his records sound incredible, more importantly FEEL incredible, because he’s constantly mixing the song, constantly making decisions. Like a shit hot live band playing off each other Andy’s faders are always moving, parts are constantly responding to other parts, decisions are being made about sonic and part priorities.

I think one of the main reasons when i asked the round table what their favorite mixes were, almost no modern mixes (last 5-10 years or so) came up.

It’s a hard concept for me to verbalize, but I think we have a lot of people focused on the wrong thing and misunderstanding WHY mixes resonated, and now they’re all chasing the wrong thing. Like my thoughts on if you asked a berklee student who the best guitarist was they’d pick some shredder, because they think technical wizardry is the benchmark, when the people whose playing makes you FEEL something tend to go way farther.

Enough mixers think that a clean 26hz and a saturated 26k is what the goal of a mix is and you end up with a bunch of songs that are really clear but really boring and uninspiring.

author: ALXCPH
content: our whole tuning systems is based on the harmonic series of stacking 5ths. because nature gives us exactly that through the overtone series. but the higher you go the more "out of tune" it goes. back in the day, before we were able to make octave, and divide them into 12 notes, you would have the concept of a low E and a High E as they wouldnt sound "in tune" when trying to find the octave though stacking 5ths or thirds or fourths or what ever interval people tried to use. we chose 5ths at is was the closest one to looping while being somewhat in tune, and the we invented 12 tone equal temperment and made compromises on each note so that the notes would loop every 12 tones.

author: ehutton21
content:
If you’re confident enough to hit various scales spanning 2+ octaves in each hand (in sync and delayed/one at a time) and you have a decently strong level of piano sight reading ability, then I’d say a piano teacher might be worth lessons every so often if it’s affordable because I’d say you’re starting to max the limits of your ability to assess your execution of technique (you’ll want someone to actually watch how you move, see where you should go, and give you specific cues on what you can shore up from there). 

But honestly when I was training classical piano regularly as a kid (good god I feel old saying that but I know I’m not lol), majority of upper level technique mishaps stemmed from struggles with proper wrist & elbow position where students would let their form slide (the more advanced the composition you were playing, the harder it became to remember your technique) and so they’d lack the actual strength and muscle twitch to hit harder moves.   That along with finger strength & dexterity would often result in stumbles or slips, which also vary based on how you strike the key. Most common error you’ll see that slows down technique is wrists dipping below the fingers a la traditional keyboard typing at any point in the playing process, and you’re never gonna swing an arpeggio or move fast enough to trill because your physical relation to the keys is what dictates proficiency. The physical aspect is why pianists are brought in so young (I started at supervised playing at 4 and I started instruction when I could get through the alphabet), because you can shape them into technique machines. 

So if you’re looking for max utility, finger drills, wrist position, and scales as much as possible is going to keep you sharp as hell.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I continually bring them up, but I think Autechre are miles ahead of everyone when it comes to this mode of composition. They're renowned for building their own Max/MSP patches that generate complex rhythm and timbre.

They're not simply building a patch and letting it run, nor are they sequencing every single note. They're controlling the parameters at a meta level and are steering their patches. They jam and improvise and capture then they edit it into something coherent if necessary.

But not always. Sometimes they get into the weeds and give it the expert painter's touch too. They've got a collaborative relationship with their tools.

author: Slow Hand
content:
These tools are magic, but they're not a miracle. It still requires work and understanding. It's just a different kind of work than we're used to doing. We shouldn't expect it read our mind and generate something amazing. It's still a computer.

This is something that Jon Castelli has touched as one of his unspoken services and something that we all do. Because of Jon's depth and breadth of musical understanding he's able to interpret prompts given to him by his clients and interpret their abstract requests with a well-realized result that hits the mark. That's a pro service that AI's still can't cover. They can't bring deep contextual understanding and interpret meaning.

As a client, if I hire an illustrator to commission a specific image I'm not just hiring them for their technical ability to render images. The best illustrators are going to have a broad and deep awareness of all styles, modes of presentation, and compositional techniques. They're going to use all of their experience and knowledge to interpret what my needs are and deliver on that. That's not a trivial thing to do. AI's are getting closer, but they're not mind readers.

Even the best contractors have to deal with clients who don't know how to ask for what they want; the "I'll know it when I see it" type of client. In the case of these AI tools we're the "client" who need to learn how to ask for what we want.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Certainly! Here’s a more detailed explanation of the chord choices:

D - - - | G - - - | Bb - - - | A - - - |
D - - - | G - - - | Bb - C#7 - | F#m7b5 B7 E7 |
The first four bars are in D major and use the I-IV-V chords (D-G-A). The fifth and sixth bars repeat this progression. In the third bar, we use the Neapolitan chord (Bb major), which is a chromatic chord that is built on the lowered second scale degree. It’s called the Neapolitan chord because it was commonly used in classical music from Naples. In the seventh bar, we start to modulate to E minor by using a ii-V-I progression in that key (F#m7b5-B7-E7). This progression is commonly used to modulate to a new key in jazz and other styles of music.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

author: Deleted User
content:
another one I’m thinking is how a lot of artists are funding their projects through gofundme or kickstarter type ask. 

The issue a lot of times is that we (musicians, engineers, producers, writers) are getting paid by artists paying out of pocket, whom also need a day job to support what they do most of the times. So what ends up happening is that we’re struggling relying on making a living paid by those who are also struggling. 

The culture of music should shift towards the direction where if the artist is able to provide enough values for people to want to hear more work from them, then people should be down to fund it. The issue is that everyone’s expenses are more likely going to be prioritizing commodities over intangible products like music. NFT seemed to attempt commodifying music, but just like modern art paintings- they just became a method of investment for monetization, avoiding taxes, or status; nor it was accessible enough for everyday people to want to get into it.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Going to rep Tailscale here.

Been investing in some infrastructure and future planning over here. The problem I was trying to solve was making my working drive available to me for when I’m away from my studio so I can continue to be responsive to clients at all times. 

Tailscale allows you to create a secure, private VPN without having to have a networking PHD and compromising your network. Basically install the client on a device, 2-factor auth into the client and any other client you have installed on any device signed in with those same credentials are available to you as if you’re on the same local network, even if you’re on another network anywhere else in the world. It’s an actual game changer.

For a variety of reasons including keeping my mastering rig lean and clean and because the rig is not always on because I don’t want to run my HVAC 24/7, I sync a clone of my working drive from my mastering rig to a drive attached to an always-on Mac in my home network that has the Tailscale client authenticated. I’ve got screen share enabled on that Mac and now from any other device, I can sign into it and grab whatever I need from that clone drive. You can install the client on virtually any device including NAS’s and mobile phones so it opens up whole new avenues in how to think about availability of your data, traveling, 3rd party cloud vs. rolling your own, etc. Tons of possibilities. Really big fan. Love the future.

https://tailscale.com/

author: Slow Hand
content:
I’m curious to know if anyone else has experienced this:

I had earbuds in this morning while working out. After a particularly heavy set I took a break and realized that the music *felt* as if it were 5 bpm slower. Considerably slower than I know the record should be. It felt like I was listening in slow motion.

Now I know athletes can perceive things like this; a tennis ball served at them can feel slow or as large as a bowling ball as their acuity improves. That’s cool and all, but here’s the thing:

My perception of tempo can shift dramatically from day to day, and I wish I knew how to make it more consistent.

I’ll work on a mix one day and it will feel like it’s pushing the tempo and flying along. Then I can sit down the following day and it is *dragging*. Sluggish. Same record. No actual change. It’s all my perception.

Has anyone figured out a strategy to minimize this phenomenon?

author: cian riordan
content: In a space that small, as much absorption as you can have will help you. Do you have a bigger room to record in or do you need the isolation? You'll likely get better sonic results if you can find a room with some more volume... that will also allow you to play with position in front of the microphone. As far as the level you should record at, if you've got any half-decent mic pre than you can go into the computer pretty conservatively. Assuming you don't have a super noisy chain, there'll be plenty of headroom in a 24 bit recording to bring it up after the fact. If you're looking for numbers, I'd shoot to get things into your DAW at around -18 dBFS. Many of the plugins modeled after analog gear tend to be happier with that level (or less if you're unsure).

author: cian riordan
content: Yes, exactly. There's no real benefit in trying to get a 'hot' signal directly into your computer... so anything totally clear of clipping should work fine. If you're in Pro Tools, you can right click the meter (any meter) and change it to RMS mode if that's useful.  Try and stay out of the yellow, and definitely out of the orange/red.

author: David Fuller
content:
Anyway: uncompressed PCM audio (.wav and .aiff) is made up of digital words generally 16 or 24 bits long recorded however many times a second for a given sample rate, for fixed point (integer) values. Each bit represents ~6dB of dynamic range. Every time you go up in level 6dB from that particular sample point, another bit flips from 0 (off) to 1 (on). The least significant bit defines your noise floor, so 16 bit audio has 96dB of dynamic range at maximum from noise floor to full scale (every bit turned on). Seems simple enough, right? And it isn't super complicated. But it has one problem: you run out of dynamic range real quick if you're changing levels with (virtual) faders at 24 bits. There are two ways around that:
1, make the mixer engine run on a much higher integer word length (like old Pro Tools HD systems, which use 48 bit integer), and the mixer automatically converts the audio (if anything is done to it, including fader moves) to 48 bit. Think of this as adding more digits to the fractions side of a decimal point. 
2, make the mixer engine run on a floating point system (almost every other DAW, including more modern versions of Pro Tools) - that is, you move *where the decimal point is* . 32 bit float effectively works as 24 bits that can be moved around more or less with impunity, up or down.

author: cian riordan
content: I juggled side-gigs for years while getting going -- but made a point for all of them to be temporary & extremely flexible. So many of my opportunities came last minute and having the ability to pivot and make things happen for people was extremely important. For example, I was living in the Bay Area working out of a studio when I reached out to Eric about assisting. He asked if I could come down to LA that weekend to interview/hang-out -- so I got on a plane. At the end of the weekend he hired me and basically said, "record starts in two weeks -- can you get down here?". I had to move out of my studio, pack up my life, find a place to live, and get down to make it happen. Obviously that was a great opportunity and most folks in my position would trip over themselves to make it happen -- but I always wondered had I had a day-job with real obligations and financial leverage over my life, would I have been able to make the timeline work... probably not!

author: rse
content: Just intonation is based on the harmonic series right? So it has really amazing sounding intervals in one key but it would sound out of wack when you switch keys? So equal temperament is a compromise to "fix" that? That's my very basic understanding of it

author: ehutton21
content: yeah, base level (which id argue is all any human being should really bother with understanding) is just scale connects to overtones and fundamentals, which relates more to stringed instruments. equal temperament has more to do with keyboards and stuff. ET uses a constant interval to define notes, which is why it gets ugly if you hit a note out of key.

author: Deleted User
content: I would read both “How Equal Temperament Ruined Harmony and Why You Should Care” by Ross Duffin + the first 130 pages of “Harmonic Experience” by Mathieu. There actually are some adjustments that can be made which would benefit certain singers. Sade for example has a tendency to sing her seconds and minor thirds pure(which makes her quite sharp in relation to ET). Also, the thirds aren’t just a “bit” off, they’re 15 cents off, which is a massive difference. It really changes the whole harmonic character of the music. I have a loooot to say on the subject, really, I’ve been studying it deeply for a few years now.

author: Deleted User
content: Blues guitar for example would sound ridiculous of you didn’t bend to pure sevenths, tritones and minor/neutral thirds. Every good blues guitarist does it intuitively(based on having heard others do it).

author: ehutton21
content: I think it’s important to remember the dollar today>dollar tomorrow point is true in the context of a choice between two deals/options that are on the table (but even then, you have to do the math to make sure! Just because you have a deal with $1500 now versus $4000 in a year doesn’t mean that you should take $1500 now, unless you need that kind of capital). To apply that logic to situations beyond the time value of money isn’t the whole picture: that law of economics only compares value, it doesn’t tell us that concentrating labor for short term gains yields the best possible business model. By that logic, there is an argument that everyone’s best business decision is to forego longterm relationship building, knowledge acquisition (which is like R&D for producers), and strictly focus on maximizing immediate sales (which could look like everyone hopping on beatstars, fiverr, and enginears) which would diminish resources like this very discord, and probably a lot of reputations too!

author: Zach Hughes
content:
There also, in casual discussions around streaming payouts, does not seem to be much of an understanding of how the value of a stream is derived and the affect of choices made by non-music interests on that derivation.

Choices such as using a pro-rata payout model vs a user centric payout model. Spotify has said they would adopt a user centric model if the general music community called for it. This would probably be better for most of us.

Or even nuance surrounding what the definition of a stream is and consideration for the type of record being streamed relative to the payout amount. A stream of a record of complete silence is worth the same as a stream of the largest scale commercial release.

author: austenballard
content:
Which brings me to one of the biggest problems here. Healthcare. Even with good insurance, you will still be paying fairly substantial amounts of money for mediocre service. Your insurance network determines which doctors and hospitals you can go to. God forbid you get sick in the wrong state and need to go to the hospital - even if you have insurance, you might end up paying out of pocket if you're not covered at your point of care. Just don't get sick, and DEFINITELY don't have any chronic illnesses.This dysfunction applies to social services in general. Where things can be privatised, they have been, and where they haven't, they don't really work.

Then there are socio-cultural factors. Politics is a spectator sport, and Americans LOVE sports. Red team and blue team *hate* each other with a passion that is unmatched by political parties pretty much anywhere there isn't an active civil war on. Related but slightly different, race-based animosity is becoming more and more of a problem again the last few years after half a century of social progress. You will be able to avoid getting dragged into this by being an expat/resident alien/what have you, but you need to be aware that it's there. Another related issue to this is education. The vast majority of people in the US did not receive anything close to an adequate education to function in the modern globalised world, even if they went to college. This leads to a lot of parochialism and narrow-mindedness that spreads bad ideas fast.

author: Maxim
content:
To Austen's point though: "*is it okay* to admit that there are situations in which all you can do is *accept fate* as it comes and try your best to *learn a lesson*"

Breaking down the key parts of that phrase — "is it okay", "accepting fate", and "learning a lesson" — to me they are in harmony with what concepts like extreme ownership try to get at. I would just replace the wording. 

It's *mandatory* to *learn a lesson* when things don't go as they were intended to. The only way forward is to accept that this older version of you wasn't up to the task but also that you are not that version of yourself anymore.

Addendum: Depending on the subject matter, previous versions of oneself might view a situation as out of their control but later might find that not the situation but they themselves were the faulty part of the equation. So it's part letting go and part failing forward.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm still formulating my thoughts, but my initial impression was that it felt more lifeless than I expected. Watching it spit out words one by one, felt like I was having a conversation with a dial up modem. Really, it felt like a more intuitive search engine, and less like it was feeding me anything I couldn't attain in other ways (through more effort).

I asked it some questions about where to find information about programming languages and it turned up some helpful resources. I spent awhile asking it to code some things for me and it did so impressively, while leaving bits in the code that explained what it was doing. I can see that being massively useful for bug-hunting, but also as a learning tool. I was fascinated when I asked it to code me a GUI for this fake program and it complied. But when I asked it to show me what that would actually look like, it linked to an IMGUR image that didn't exist.

If I walked away with one feeling, it was curiosity, instead of anything negative.

author: shaunobi
content: The second thing though is when the job itself doesn't have the "thing" anymore. Sometimes this is because it morphed - gig work (which I do just at a very large scale) can really suck the joy out of you. Here you are working, but you're also marketing, you're doing sales, you're chasing payment, you're reviewing contracts, you're "presenting" yourself to other people, you're worried about seasonality, you're thinking about healthcare and taxes and retirement, and you're doing it ALL YOURSELF. I don't work for a big company (I run a small one) but my wife does, and the nice thing here is: you just show up and do YOUR job, you're a nurse and you take care of folks, you're an accountant and you reconcile spreadsheets, etc. Instead we do EVERY job with zero economies of scale, and no matter how much you try to "outsource" it, that costs money, it costs oversight and time and initial effort, and in the end it's a lot.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm trying to zoom out here. Like, what is the actual revenue being brought in by the artists you're hoping to work with? Where is money to be made and who's making it? 

Picking a nice round number, if you're an engineer on an album that gets a million streams a year, that's something like $4000 for the artist. Hopefully they generate money from touring, but based on the album's services alone, how much could an artist reasonably pay if their ROI is $4k?

If the gamble is to get hooked up with a new artist who has the potential to break through, the producer's points on a hit is where real money could be made, right? So pricing yourself to get at many chances at the lottery would likely be more fruitful than a few extra hundred per gig, but it's a gamble. Between repeat clients and chance for a moderate hit, it seems like a better way to spend your time

All that said, as you pointed out, this ain't my lane.

author: Will Melones
content:
I guess it depends heavily on scale. $40 a month just to keep the doors open sounds steep for an artist who isn't already selling merch at a consistent rate. I haven't looked at Shopify's print on demand pricing, but in general POD is much higher cost than bulk screen printing t-shirts (for example). So if you're a band selling at the scale where $40/mo. on a slow month isn't your *entire* profit margin, it seems like investing in a run of merch would pay for itself.

Now this is completely different if you look at it from the perspective of a clothing brand, where the goal is to have a diversity of designs available at all times, without the need for warehousing and a huge startup cost, and to consistently push sales to a customer base that's devoted to *the merch*. I can't imagine the vast majority of DistroKid artists are going that hard on ecommerce, but they could sure benefit from having their POD merch visible on their Spotify profile. The small artists I work with would probably be better off putting $40 into Instagram ads every month.

author: jantrit
content:
Sometimes you can see them coming a mile away and sometimes you can’t. I feel like the more I do this the easier it becomes to spot and the scales are starting to tip heavily into you see it coming side. I find it helpful to think of each time as a case by case sort of thing. Are you young and just coming up trying to cut your teeth or in a quieter than usual month with bills looming? Then probably you’ll end up saying yes to more things that you would usually swerve. Are you busier than ever beating off business with a 10ft pole, then maybe you don’t need to take this gig. I try and deal with it preemptively in this way, can it be avoided before we’ve even begun? In which case I’d probably swerve the project. If you’re already in deep and working I’d try and just power through like you said. You can always say no next time. If it’s just not possible to do that and you actually have to get out for the sake of your sanity, it might be worth speaking to the artist and saying “hey I’m really sorry but I don’t think I’m best placed here to help you achieve your goals” depending on reasons why you could even recommend someone who might be a better fit (if the person is a total dick I absolutely would not do this)

That’s really a last resort though. Powering through, learning from it (even just being able to spot these things before they start) and giving yourself the ability to swerve them in the future. 

Can I ask what the situation is and what’s making you want to dump the project?

Edit:
I’ve only ever had to ‘fire’ one client in my time (it may about to be two) the first time it honestly worked out better for everyone involved.

author: Will Melones
content:
Shouldn’t they care to know? I’ve heard so many people in my family say they have no musical talent or they’re terrible at piano, but they’ve never practiced for 15 minutes. What’s the measurable difference between Yo-Yo Ma and your uncle?

My gut feeling is that most of talent comes down to commitment/focus (interest in the craft) and learning styles, and then culture and early exposure mold that into an affinity.

Some people will suck at an art form, put in the work, and then not suck anymore. Some will be born with a brain that’s wired to seeing shapes, and find it easy to visualize patterns on a guitar neck. Some will be auditory learners and may find it easier to learn to identify intervals by ear.

And then some people will grow up singing or playing in church, and those people get the cheat codes from a *very* young age while their brains are still spongey, learning things like their first language. Of course they weren’t born playing the organ, but it can look that way from the outside.

It seems both mystical and defeatist when people who don’t think they have talent talk about people who do—almost like an excuse. And maybe that’s intentional, and exactly the point you’re making.

No worries. If you aren’t throttled on performance on those devices you don’t need to juggle your TB distro. If you don’t need the afterburner I’d take it out. But that’s up to you.

author: popthetrunk
content:
Great! Re: black magic stuff, that’s out of my domain and I can’t really advise on a decklink. But that would move the load off TB(strictly pool b) and place it on the available pcie(pool a+b)

That owc 8m2 takes 16 lanes, the bandwidth of a single pool, or it can fully saturate slot 3 without impacting the pools. Changing model wise to the 4m2 which can fit in an 8 lane slot isn’t a terrible idea if you don’t need the capacity

author: Deleted User
content:
there are traditional jazz and modern jazz. people who do traditional like to honor the head (the melody of jazz standard). A close friend of mine is a modern Jazz Saxophonist, he said he once broke up with his band after an argument because he didn’t want to play the melody but his band members were more traditional and wanted him to play the head. 

Imo calling something not Jazz because they aren’t doing the head-solo-head form is like calling modern classical music not classical music because of the aleatoric composition. Somewhat of a valid opinion, but not really. 

Would you call wayne shorter not a jazz musician because he writes scores for his band? (well… he’s also a free jazz musician…) 

For general public, traditional jazz and traditional classical music would be more appealing to listen to for most people due to the predictability factor. Modern classical music and modern jazz is a movement to explore creative possibilities beyond that, but… it’s often not done so tastefully because they step too far off the predictability.

But Jazz is a free form of expression. I think a lot of non-jazz musicians hate on Jazz because it’s somewhat cerebral (it really isn’t once you get past it… which I couldn’t just yet), and a lot of people choose music because of its unexplainable magic people experience from it. It’s only natural that the same people that was attracted to the unexplainable nature of music being turned off by the explainable nature of harmonies and rhythms. Jazz noobs and Berklee kids may make it look like that what Jazz is about and some have elitism behind it too, but that’s not jazz. All the theory and stuff is a door you go through to be able to step into the world of self expression with an open form. (to be fair many old school jazz musicians solely played by ear with no knowledge in music theory. because… it all comes from their ears at the end of the day)

Whether one wants to sit through someone expressing themselves is theirs to decide.

author: spectrummasters
content:
Internal to the neuron, everything works via biochemical pathways, which are somewhat similar to analog. Neurons also perform internal electrical signal integration in an analog fashion. Analogously, the digital logic gates used by computers are implemented internally using transistors and resistors, which are also analog.

This recording of neural spikes over time shows that the spatiotemporal pulses of the neural code looks a lot like digital signaling:

content: My drum teacher used to have me mold my perception by listening to the song stretched even slower for a bit if it felt slow, or stretched even faster for a bit if it feels fast. If you do it for a bit and go back to the original tempo, it usually resets.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm sure there's some amazing new tech out today, but the biggest bang for your buck that I know is an algorithm akin to what Ableton's *Beats* warp mode does:

1. Slice the audio file at each transient.
2. Globally apply fades to the end of each slice.

This has the effect of drying up the verb on each slice. That said, I'm sure it's effectiveness is very dependent on the source material.

author: Pio
content:
They’re so good. I used one earlier this year when I wanted to lock in on some writing work for a bit and go fairly heftily cold turkey offline, for a few weeks - I let my brother come and visit me and hide the Brick somewhere in my house where I couldn’t find it. 

I would have had to call him, and ask him to come visit me, if I wanted to unlock it… and… it worked 😂

Of course most of the time I use it a bit more reasonably 😅 but it’s amazing the difference it makes doing something simple like putting it in another room so you’ll have to go all the way over there to get back online

Definitely been a game changer

author: popthetrunk
content:
You can’t boot a drive you use as a Time Machine backup directly as in the past. 

But you can make an external disk bootable by installing macOS to an APFS disk via the regular installer or from macOS Recovery. 

You could then restore a Time Machine backup to this bootable disk, and then boot your restored OS.

On Apple Silicon the install needs to be done from a port other than the device firmware update(DFU) port, easy to look up which one for your model. But you can boot from any port after. You’ll need to change the security mode in the Startup Security Utility on the machine you are booting to Reduced Security, also just enable kernel extensions while you are there if you need for an interface like UAD etc.

This bootable OS will be specific to your Mac Model, as in, a m4 mbp installed external will not boot an m2 Mac mini or an m5 mbp etc. I’m not sure if it needs to be the same specs, but that could easily be tested
